Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
2 or more of the following
•Temp >{{c1::38}} degC or <{{c1::36}} degC
•Heart rate >{{c1::90}} bpm
•Respiratory rate >{{c1::20}} breaths/min
•WCC >{{c1::12,000}} (leukocytosis) or <{{c1::4,000}} per mm3 (leukopenia)
•(Bedside blood glucose >{{c1::7.7}} mmol/L (in absence of DM))

{{c1::Sepsis}}:  life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection

 Clinical suspicion of infection plus one of following presentations:
 Unwell patient at risk of {{c1::neutropenia}}; 
 Clinical evidence of new onset organ failure: acute altered mental status, oliguria/anuria, non-{{c1::blanching}} rash, hypotension, hypoxia, etc.
 ≥ 2 {{c1::SIRS}} criteria plus ≥ 1 co-morbidities eg. COPD, DM, chronic liver/renal disease, cancer, advanced age, immunosuppressive Rx, major surgery/trauma, etc.

neutropenia: low neutrophils
non-blanching: don't disappear with pressure

{{c1::Infective endocarditis}}: Bacterial (or fungal) infection of a heart valve or area of endocardium

Pathogenesis
Host factors
•Pre-existing valvular {{c1::lesions}} eg. congenital, rheumatic fever, aortic sclerosis in elderly patients
•Congenital cardiac abnormalities causing {{c1::turbulent}} blood flows.
•Prosthetic {{c1::valves}}

Risks for bacteraemia
•Poor oral hygiene (dental/gingival conditions) – {{c1::viridans}} streptococci, etc.
•Invasive procedures / intravascular lines – {{c1::staphyl}}ococci, etc.
•Deep seated infections, etc.

Characteristics of infecting organisms:
• Virulence of organism eg. {{c1::S. aureus}} -> acute course
• Ability to adhere and colonise damaged endothelium or prosthetic surfaces
• Streptococci, staphylococci & enterococci (ie. Gram{{c1::-positive}} cocci) together are responsible for >{{c1::80}}% of cases.

complications of endocarditis
Local
•{{c1::Valvular}} destruction and incompetence
• Valvular root {{c1::abscess}}
• Cardiopulmonary complications eg. ventricular hypertrophy, heart failure, pulmonary oedema

Metastatic
 Hands/feet: splinter haemorrhages, nail-fold infarcts, {{c1::Osler}}’s nodes, {{c1::Janeway}} lesions, etc.
 Eyes: Retina - {{c1::Roth}} spots; conjunctival haemorrhages
 Deep organs:
 Infarction – {{c1::splenic and renal}} infarcts, etc.
 Abscess formation – bone/joint; brain abscesses; pulmonary embolism/abscesses; etc.

Other
• Acute {{c1::renal}} failure -secondary to IE or to treatment – aminoglycosides and/or glycopeptides
• Mycotic aneurysms
• Death
Vegetation is a hallmark of endocarditis

Subacute native valve endocarditis
is {{c1::less}} aggressive

 Risk factors:
•Congenital heart disease (high to lower pressure gradients greatest risk)
•Rheumatic {{c1::Heart}} Disease
•{{c1::Mitral}} valve prolapse
•Degenerative valve lesions

What is biofilm?

Biofilm formation 

a process whereby microorganisms irreversibly attach to and grow on a surface and produce extracellular polymers that facilitate attachment and matrix formation, resulting in an alteration in the phenotype of the organisms with respect to growth rate and gene transcription.

Prevention of early-onset infections in such devices
Pre- / Peri-operative measures:
{{c1::Skin}} preparation
{{c1::Sterile}} equipment
Surgical technique; Operating environment
{{c1::Antimicrobial}} prophylaxis

Post-operative measures:
Hand hygiene; optimal wound management;
Nutritional support, glycaemic control, etc.

Prevention of late-onset infections in such devices
-Minimise risk of {{c1::bactaeremia}} eg. avoidance of high-risk activities if possible eg. body-piercing, tattoing, etc.
-Prompt treatment of any infections
-Optimising general health: nutrition, exercise, BMI, oral hygiene, management of underlying conditions, etc.

Case history
 46-year-old man sustained multiple injuries in a road traffic accident. He spent 8 days in the surgical ICU, and required surgery and transfusion of several units of packed red blood cells.
 
 In the early morning he developed 
a fever of 39.6°C. 
His pulse was 110 beats per minute; 
blood pressure 113/56 mm Hg; 
and his respiratory rate was 20 breaths/minute. 

His lungs were clear bilaterally; and his abdomen soft & non-tender. A right internal jugular CVC was in place with no erythema at the exit site. 

 His white blood cell (WBC) count had increased to 15.8. A portable chest x-ray showed no infiltrate. Two sets of blood cultures were drawn and the patient was started empirically on piperacillin/tazobactam by the physician. The laboratory notified the clinician that both sets of blood cultures flagged positive for Gram-positive cocci:
◦Via CVC lumen: positive after 7 hrs of incubation
◦Via peripheral vein: positive after 12 hrs of incubation

 What else would you like to know from the laboratory?
 Are the Gram-positive cocci in clusters or in chains.
 What changes, if any, would you make now?
 Consider addition of glycopeptide

 The patient was started on vancomycin 1 g IV every 12 hours, and a second set of blood cultures was drawn. Overnight he had another temperature spike to 38.6°C, and the next morning his WBC count rose to 16.5. His follow-up blood cultures also flagged positive for gram-positive cocci in clusters. The organism from his first set of cultures was identified as S. aureus. Susceptibilities were pending.
 
 What else, if any, would you do now?
 Removal of the CVC

 The patient's CVC was removed and the tip of the catheter was sent for a semi-quantitative culture. Over the next 24 hours he defervesced. The susceptibility results of S. aureus blood isolate were as follow:
◦Oxacillin-sensitive; Vancomycin-sensitive.
◦The catheter tip was also culture-positive for S. aureus.
 
 What changes, if any, would you make now?
 Change Rx to IV flucloxacillin (or nafcillin)

 What other investigations would you consider?
 Echocardiography to rule out complication of endocarditis (In some studies, up to 10% of S. aureus bacteraemia cases were complicated by endocarditis)

Repeat blood cultures to ensure the elimination of S. aureus from the bloodstream
 
Monitor the patient to rule out complications arising from the bloodstream infection

Zoonotic tuberculosis
§Tuberculosis acquired from infected animals/animal products
§Main organism: Mycobacterium {{c1::bovis}}
§Zoonotic TB a global problem in developing countries
§Close contacts with infected animals (farmers, vets, etc.) or foodborne infection, eg. unpasteurised milk
§Foodborne infection: infection of tonsils, cervical lymph nodes, GIT, urinary tract, bone/joint, etc.
§Rare in Ireland; majority have very low risk of exposure/infection:
§Annual TB testing of cattle herds; prompt elimination of infected ones from milk-producing herds
§{{c1::Pasteurisation}} of milk

Clinical course of disease
Primary infection:
->  Active infection (<10%)
-> Self-limiting infection leading to:
latency of infection (~90%)
↓
Reactivation of disease ({{c1::5-15}}%)
↓
  Pulmonary or extra-pulmonary

Primary infection
§Initial alveolar infection with spread with lymphatics to {{c1::hilar}} lymph nodes. Possible dissemination via bloodstream

§90%: development of cellular immunity about 6 weeks later: infective foci in lungs or elsewhere -> small {{c1::granuloma}} (lymphocytes, macrophages, epithelioid cells and small area of central caseation -> transition to latency of disease

§Minority of patients – progression into active disease

Primary TB pneumonia
§Fever, chest pain, cough, fatigue

§Radiological:
pulmonary infiltrates (consolidation)
 


§peri-hilar lymphadenopathy,
§pleural effusion (1/3).


What is Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy? 
{{c1::It is a bilateral enlargement of the lymph nodes of pulmonary hila. It is a radiographic term for the enlargement of mediastinal lymph nodes and is most commonly identified by a chest x-ray.}}

Minority of primary infections:
§Disseminated ({{c1::miliary}}) primary infection: multiple organ systems including CNS ({{c1::meningitis}})

Outcome of Latent TB
§Majority of latent TB cases remain latent throughout lifetime.
§Granulomas remain localised & quiescent, and become encapsulated by {{c1::fibrous}} tissue plus calcification of central caseation

§But 5-15% cases of latent disease: progression from dormancy to active disease (ie. reactivation)
§Approx half within next 5 years and half some years thereafter
§Characterised by enlargement of {{c1::granulomas}}, liquefaction of caseous area and proliferation of bacteria
§Over a few months, patients become symptomatic. Clinical features depend on site of reactivated disease

§Pulmonary (2/3)

§Extra-pulmonary (1/3)
  Kidneys, adrenal glands,
  gastrointestinal tract,
  bones, meninges, etc

§Systemic symptoms: intermittent {{c1::fever}}, night sweats, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, etc.

§Pulmonary: cough, haemoptysis, chest pain, etc.

§Bone: pain, tenderness, +/- neurological features

§CNS: subacute meningitis, headache, confusion, personality changes, seizures, cranial nerve palsies, etc.

§Renal: symptoms of cystitis; ‘sterile’ pyuria;
  others: back/flank pain, haematuria, etc.

Reactivated pulmonary tuberculosis
§Most often in the posterior and apical segments of the {{c1::upper}} lobe (85%)
§Less often in the anterior segment of upper lobe or superior segment of lower lobe
§Cavitation more likely than in primary infection

What is Cavitation?
{{c1::Dead, or necrotic, tissue tends to tear and break down. In the lung, this is called 'cavitation', after the latin word for cave. It is thought that the TB bacilli destroy the lung tissue in a cave formation, where more and more of them sit in the middle and slowly destroy more tissue at the edges.}}

§More difficult to diagnose TB

§Active TB leads to more rapid progression of HIV infection
§Higher mortality in co-infected patients

Inflammation
Protective, dynamic response of blood vessels and leukocytes to injury

Acute Inflammation
Rapid host response to tissue injury 🡪 short duration
  • Deliver leukocytes and anti{{c1::bodies}} to site of infection/tissue injury
  • Destroys, dilutes or walls off injurious agent
  • Triggers wave of repair
  • Protective response can be harmful
  • Characteristics: exudation of {{c1::fluid/plasma protein}} in form of oedema and emigration of {{c1::leukocytes (neutrophils)}}
What's difference of acute v. chronic inflamm, for time course and cells involved?

Acute Inflammation Causes
Give 4 causes
  • {{c1::
    • Microbial infections 🡪 bacterial, viral, fungal
    • Tissue necrosis 🡪 ischaemia, trauma, physical/chemical
    • Foreign bodies
    • Hypersensitive reactions 🡪 chronic problems with waves of acute inflammation
    }}
  • Signs of AI 🡪 site dependent and tend to occur externally
  • Rubor: {{c1::redness}}
  • Tumor: {{c1::swelling}}
  • Calor: {{c1::heat 🡪 no increase in heat dependent internally}}
  • Dolor: {{c1::pain 🡪 only where there are appropriate nerve endings (e.g. in lung no pain unless at pleura)}}
  • Functio laesa: {{c1::loss of function}}
Explain each of those terms

Sequence of events
  • Phagocytes and other {{c1::sentinel}} cells recognise presence of foreign substance and release cytokines, lipid messengers…
  • Some mediators act on small blood vessels and promote {{c1::ef}}flux of plasma and recruitment of circulating leukocytes to the site
  • Vasodilation 🡪 increase in blood flow
  • Increased vascular permeability 🡪 enabling plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave
  • Emigration of leukocytes 🡪 accumulation and activation

Mechanisms of acute inflamm
  • Alteration of vascular calibre: brief vasoconstriction, why?{{c1::(prevent spread of noxious agent)}}🡪 vasodilation 🡪 increased blood flow and blood pooling 🡪 redness and warmth (rubor and calor)
  • Changes of microvasculature: increased permeability for plasma proteins and cells 🡪 swelling (tumor) 🡪 fluid loss 🡪 conc of RBC and slowed blood flow (stasis)
  • Emigration of leukocytes: due to {{c1::stasis}} 🡪 activation leads migration towards site
  • Mechanisms of increased vascular permeability
  • Endothelial cell contraction: by Histamine, leukotrienes, bradykinin, mainly in venules. Short lived ({{c1::15-30}} min) 🡪 regulated moderate fluid exudation
  • Direct damage to endothelium: endothelial cell (EC) necrosis and detachment – arterioles, capillaries and venules. Long lived (hours – days) 🡪 unregulated, excessive fluid exudation (burns)
  • Neutrophils: Adhere to {{c1::endothelium}} during inflammation and injure EC – venules, pulmonary capillaries. Late stage inflammation, long lived (hours)
  • {{c1::Transcytosis}}: Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the EC via channels – venules – induced by {{c1::VEGF}} 🡪 contribution not as certain as other 3 processes

• Manifestations of acute inflammation
  • Oedema: Extravascular fluid in the interstitial tissue or serous cavities
  • Normally net flow across vascular bed is negligible as {{c1::osmotic}} pressure is equal on both sides
  • {{c1::Vascular}} permeability changes this 🡪 fluid leakage (exudate)
  • Exudate – via increased permeability – associated with AI
  • Filtrate of plasma, inflammatory cells and cellular debris
  • Permeability of endothelium altered
  • High protein count
  • Transudate – via increase in hydrostatic pressure in vessel - NOT associated with {{c1::inflammation}}
  • Ultrafiltrate of plasma
  • Normal permeability of endothelium
  • Low protein content (mostly {{c1::albumin}})
  • Little/no {{c1::cellular}} material 
  • Increased pressure can occur in lungs (congestive heart failure) or decreased colloid osmotic pressure (decreased {{c1::protein}} synthesis in liver)
After vascular inflammation 🡪 neutrophil influx

Stages of inflammation
  • Margination and rolling
  • Inflammatory mediators activate endothelial cells to increase expression of adhesion molecules on surface
  • Adhesion molecules: Transmembrane heterodimeric {{c1::glycoproteins}} 🡪 (normally inactive) activated to attract leukocytes 🡪 weak transient interactions of leukocytes with endothelium 🡪 mediated rolling of leukocyte along surface
  • Interactions: Involve selectin family 🡪 E and P selectins on endothelial cells bind to glycoproteins on leukocytes (CD{{c1::34}}, Sialyl-Lewis X-modified GP) 🡪 upregulated by cytokines (histamine, TNF, IL-{{c1::1}})
  • Adhesion
  • Rolling stops 🡪 adhesion with {{c1::integrin}} participation
  • Endothelial _ ligands: ICAM-1, VCAM01
  • Leukocyte _: LFA-1, Mac1, VLA-4
  • Transmigration (diapedesis)
  • After firm adhesion within systemic venules and pulm capillaries via {{c1::PECAM-1 (CD31)}} (mediates binding events)
  • Cross basement membrane 🡪 integrins, collagenases produced by leukocytes
  • Mediated by {{c1::chemotaxis}}

• Leukocyte infiltrate varies
  • Early: oedema (neutrophil infiltrate) 
  • Chronic: Monocyte and macrophage infiltration
  • Chemotaxis of Leukocytes
  • L. emigrate to site of injury via chemical gradient of chemoattractants
  • Chemoattractants
  • Exogenous: {{c1::bacterial}} products 🡪 N-formyl-methionyl peptides
  • Endogenous: complement (C{{c1::3a}} and {{c1::5a}}), {{c1::Leukotrienes}} (LTB4), chemokines (IL-{{c1::8}})
  • G-protein coupled receptors 🡪 induces movement of the leukocyte through morphological changes in cytoskeleton 🡪 activation of leukocytes through pattern recognition receptors ({{c1::opsonin}}) 🡪 induce neutrophil and macrophage effector fxn (production of further mediators, ROS and lysosomal enzymes to kill microbes)
  • Leukocyte effector fxn: phagocytosis 🡪 release of bactericidal and cytoxic molecules

Phagocytosis
  • Recognition and attachment
  • Engulfment and fusion of phagosome and lysosome
  • Killing and degradation of ingested material
  • Phagosomes fuse with {{c1::lysosomal}} granules 🡪 phagolysosome 🡪 bacteriocidal and cell degrading enzymes digest the microbe/dead cells
  • NADPH oxidase system: membrane bound enzyme complex, reduces O2 to O2- (oxidative burst)
  • NO: produced from action of iNOS on arginine reacts with O2- 🡪 ONOO- attacks (3) {{c1::lipid membranes, protein and nucleic acids of microbes}}
  • H2O2: converted to hydrochlorous radical HOCl’ by {{c1::myeloperoxidase}}

Acute Inflamm mediators
  • Vascular and cellular responses of inflammation are mediated by soluble factors (derived from blood plasma/produced by cells) and triggered by inflammatory stimuli
  • {{c1::Eicosanoids}}: mediate every step of inflammation
  • Cell derived local mediators – pre-formed in granules (degranulation releases)
  • Vasoactive amine: stored as preformed molecules in secretory granules 🡪 first to be released in inflammation (degranulation)
  • Histamine: Causes vasodilation and increased permeability of vasculature
  • Lysosomal enzymes: in neutrophils and macrophages degrade microbes in phagocytosis
  • {{c1::Serotonin}}: found in platelets and neuroendocrine cells of GIT 🡪 vasodilation indirectly by inducing {{c1::NO}} synthesase 🡪 _

• Vaso{{c1::dilation}}: PCI1, PGE1, PGE2, PGD2
  • Vaso{{c1::constriction}}: Thromboxane A2, Leukotriene C4, D4, E4
  • {{c1::Increased}} vascular permeability: LTC4, LTD4, LTE4
  • Chemotaxis, leukotriene adhesion: LTB4, 5-HETE
  • Pain mediation, fever induction: {{c1::PGE2}}
  • NO: Relaxes vascular smooth muscle and promotes vasodilation AND {{c1::inhibits}} leukocyte recruitment

  • Cytokines and chemokines
  • Proteins produced my many cell types
  • Name 3 factors {{c1::TNF, IL-1 and IL-6}} 🡪 promote leukocyte recruitment
  • Activate production of adhesion molecules and leukocytes 🡪 trigger production of further cytokines
  • Induce systemic acute effects 🡪 fever
  • Induce acute phase proteins from liver ({{c1::c-reactive protein}} (CRP) and fibrinogen)
  • CRP and erythrocyte sedimentation rate used as measures of therapeutic response 
  • Stimulate hemopoietic system of bone marrow 🡪 produce leukocytes
  • Leukocyte count: 15-20,000 cells/ml in inflammation
  • Pathological effects: Increase hr and bp, clotting and {{c1::inhibition}} of insulin signal transduction in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle
Chemokines: act as chemoattractants for leukocytes (40 chemokines, 20 receptors)

• Eicosanoid generation from arachidonic acid in cell membrane
  • Phospholipases and downstream cyclooxygenases and lipoxygenases are key for production
  • Steroids: Block {{c1::phospholipases}}
  • COX 1/2 inhibitors or NSAIDs: Block {{c1::Cyclooxygenases}}
  • Lipoxygenase inhibitors: Block {{c1::lipoxygenases}}

Systemic Mediators
  • Factor {{c1::XII}}: Hagman, circulates in blood until it encounters damaged epithelium 🡪 triggers 4 cascades contributing to inflammation
  • Kinin cascade: Bradykinin 🡪 increase vascular permeability and (vein or art.) {{c1::arteriolar}} dilation
  • Clotting cascade: {{c1::Thrombin}} 🡪 enhances leukocyte adhesion
  • Fibrinolytic system: Plasmin 🡪 cleaves fibrin and C{{c1::3}} of complement cascade🡪 fibrin products increase vascular permeability
  • Complement cascade: increase vascular permeability, leukocyte chemotaxis and generates holes in membranes of invading microbes 🡪 lysis
  • Cleavage of C3 for activation 
  • classical pathway: fixation of C{{c1::1}} to antibodies IgM/IgG) 
  • Alternative pathway: triggered by microbial surface molecules, endotoxin or LPS, complex polysaccharides, cobra venom in absence of antibody
  • {{c1::Lectin}} pathway: plasma lectin binds mannose residues on microbes and directly activates C1, like a smart bomb
  • 3 pathways lead to formation of C3 convertase which cleaves C3 to C3a and C3b
  • C3a: Mediated effector functions of leukocytes
  • C3b: phagocytosis and cell lysis
  • After C1 or C3b recognise and bind an injured cell, a proteolytic signalling cascade is initiated 🡪 generation of C3 convertase 🡪 C5 convertase 🡪 activates cleavage of C5a/band C5a attract basophils and eosinophils to damaged tissue
  • C5a: induces infiltration of leukocytes, monocytes and macrophages
  • CNS: {{c1::microglia}} similarly activated by complement system
Attack complex C5-B9: lysis of selected cell populations (bacteria etc)

Morphological Patterns of Acute Inflammation (EXUDATE)

Mix and match these
Serous (watery)
Purulent
Necrotising/Ulcerative
Hemorrhagic inflammation
Catarrhal inflammation
Fibrinous


  • {{c1::
    • Serous Inflammation
    }}
  • Marked by outpouring of thin protein rich fluid with low cellular content
  • Accumulation of fluid derived from plasma as a result of increased permeability or mesothelial cells secretions within body cavities
  • Skin blister from burn/viral infection represents large accumulation of serous fluid (also runny nose in hayfever)
  • Image on bottom: _ exudate in thoracic cavity


  • {{c1::
    • Catarrhal Inflammation
    }}
  • Mucous hypersecretion
  • Exclusively on mucus membranes
  • Acute rhinitis (common cold – snotty nose), acute catarrhal bronchitis, enteritis
  • Affects mucus membranes of respiratory tract and GIT 🡪 produces watery exudate of serum and mucus 
  • Photo = enteritis


  • {{c1::
    • Purulent Inflammation
    }}
  • Production of large amounts of pus or _ exudate consisting of neutrophils (high cellular content)
  • Certain pyogenic (pus-producing) bacteria (staph/strep) 
  • {{c1::Abscesses}}: localised collections of purulent inflammatory tissue caused by suppuration buried in a tissue/organ/confined space
  • Brown/histology: lung
  • Other: appendix


  • {{c1::
    • Fibrinous Inflammation
    }}
  • Severe injuries with greater vascular permeability 🡪 large molecules like fibrinogen pass through and fibrin is formed and deposited
  • _ exudate 🡪 inflammation in lining of body cavities (meninges, pericardium and pleura) 🡪 can lead to permanent scarring


  • {{c1::
    • Haemorrhagic Inflammation
    }}
  • Exudative inflammation involving microvascular injury with massive microvascular bleeding 🡪 exudate with high erythrocyte content
  • Pneumonia, acute pancreatitis, viral haem fever, anthrax, enterohaemorrhagic E. coli
  • Histology: _ pneumonia (photo is pancreatitis)


  • {{c1::
    • Necrotising/Ulcerative Inflammation
    }}
  • {{c1::Ulcer}}: local defect of surface of organ/tissue that is produced by sloughing (shedding) of inflammatory necrotic tissue
  • Inflammatory necrosis of mucosa of mouth, stomach, intestines, genitourinary, necrotising fasciitis (right image)
  • Photo = duodenal ulcer

A: {{c1::Leukotriene B4}}

• Chronic Inflammation: Pathological inflammation of prolonged duration in which inflammation, tissue injury and healing proceed simultaneously
  • Characterised by: concurrent active {{c1::inflammation}}, tissue destruction, attempts at repair by {{c1::fibrosis}}
  • Causes: Give 2/3
  • {{c1::
  • Persistent infections (TB, syphilis)
  • Prolonged exposure to causative agents (Exogenous 🡪 Silicosis: found in sand/rock/mineral ore, Endogenous 🡪 atherosclerosis)
  • Immune hyperresponsiveness (Asthma, AI disease)
    • }}
  • Chronic Inflammation – Morphological features
  • Most acute features remain but WBC infiltration changes from short lived neutrophilic infiltration to long term (2/3){{c1::macrophages and lymphocytes and dendritic}} cells
  • Infiltration with mononuclear cells (monocytes, macrophages dendritic cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells) 🡪 Indicates persistent reaction to injury
  • Tissue destruction 🡪 Induced by way of {{c1::inflammatory}} cells
Repair involving angiogenesis and fibrosis 🡪 attempt to replace lost tissue and proliferation of fibroblasts and accumulation of excess EC matrix

Chronic inflammation of lung
Acute: Structure of tissue remains intact
Chronic: Infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells (lymphocytes/macrophages), destruction of {{c1::parenchyma}}, normal alveoli are replaced by spaces lined with {{c1::cuboidal}} epithelium and complete replacement of the alveoli by connective tissue (pale pink fibrotic tissue)

Macrophages
  • Derived from circulating monocytes which reach the site of injury and transform
  • Monocyte 🡪 short lived (differentiate into macrophage or dendritic), smaller cell
  • Tissue macrophages: {{c1::Kupffer}} 🡪 liver, microglial 🡪 brain, alveolar 🡪 lungs (resident cells and derived from embryonic stem cells)
  • Long life span
  • Macrophages are activated by immune receptors (TLR) and cytokines ({{c1::IFN-y}}) secreted by T-Helper and {{c1::NK}} cells
  • Activated macrophages: Powerful phagocytic and secrete;
  • ROS and NO 🡪 toxic to bacteria 
  • {{c1::Acid}} and neutral proteases 🡪 hydrolyse protein bonds between AA
  • Cytokines/chemotactic factor 🡪 propagate response
  • {{c1::Growth}}factor 🡪 induce fibroblast proliferation, collagen proliferation, angiogenesis
  • Responsible for tissue injury and destruction

• Classical M1 activation pathway
  • Activated by microbial products and T cell derived {{c1::IFN-y}}
  • Responsible for eliminating microbes and further recruitment of immune cells
  • Alternative M2
  • Activated by cytokines (2) {{c1::IL-13, IL-4}}
  • Produce growth factors which trigger fibroblast and endothelial cell proliferation with synthesis of collagen and enzymes
  • Mechanisms of macrophage accumulation at site of inflammation
  • Continued recruitment of monocytes from circulation 🡪 most important source of macrophages
  • Local proliferation of macrophages
  • Immobilization of macrophages within the site of inflammation 🡪 cytokines and {{c1::oxidised}} lipids can cause immobilization
  • Effects of macrophage activation
  • Hyperactivity of macrophages 🡪 tissue destruction 🡪 trigger further activation of inflammatory cascade 🡪 features of acute and chronic can coexist

Lymphocyte
  • B lymphocytes: Mature to plasma cells 🡪 induce {{c1::antibody}} mediated response
  • Lymphoid nodes can occur in chronic inflammation
  • T lymphocytes: Cell mediated reaction (don’t directly recognise antigens)
  • T-cytotoxic 🡪 CD8 (MH4 🡪 perforin 🡪 granzyme cascade)
  • T-Helper 🡪 CD4 (bind peptides displayed on MH2)
  • TH{{c1::1}} 🡪 IFN-y 🡪 Activate macrophages through classical pathway
  • TH{{c1::2}} 🡪 IL4/13 🡪 Activate macrophages through alternative pathway
  • TH{{c1::17}} 🡪 IL-17 chemokines
  • T-cells and B-cells activate each other)
  • Macrophage-lymphocyte bidirectional interactions in CI
  • Activate T-cells produce cytokines (TNF, IL-17, chemokines that recruit more monocytes and others that activate macrophages 🡪 IFN-y)
  • Activated macrophages activate T cells by presenting {{c1::antigens}} and secretion of IL-12 which stimulates T-cell responses
  • Positive feedback loop

Other cells involved
  • Eosinophils: 0.5-1% leukocytes
  • Recruited to fight parasitic infections
  • Mediated by {{c1::IgE}}
  • {{c1::Eotaxin}}: Chemokine that primes eosinophils for chemotaxis
  • Allergic asthma
  • Mast cells
  • Parasitic infection
  • Located in mucosa, skin, blood vessel walls
  • Widely distributed in {{c1::connective}} tissues and participate in both acute and persistent inflammatory reactions
  • Binds to Fc portion of IgE antibody 🡪 degranulation 🡪 release histamine 🡪 allergic reaction
  • Neutrophils:
  • Polymorphonuclear cells 🡪 most abundant WBC 🡪 first line of defence against invading microbes
  • Found in chronic and acute 🡪 either new waves of acute or stimulated by persistent presence of microbes/mediators
  • Primary granules: present in all granulocytes and contain {{c1::myeloperoxidase}} which creates antibacterial compound 🡪 acid hydrolases and defences
  • Secondary granules: Most numerous type 🡪 contain complement activators and enzymes (collagenases that break down EC matrixes)
  • Interaction with pathogen: Direct through PAMPs through PRRs or indirect by recognition of microbes through Fc or complement receptors
What are PAMPs and PRRs?
{{c1::The innate immune system constitutes the first line of defense against invading microbial pathogens and relies on a large family of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs), which detect distinct evolutionarily conserved structures on pathogens, termed pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)}}

Granulomatous inflammation
  • Chronic inflammatory reaction in which predominant cells are macrophages
  • Aggregations of macrophages have enlarged {{c1::squamous}} cell-like appearance 🡪 Epithelioid macrophages
  • {{c1::Granuloma}}: Nodular collection of epithelioid macrophages surrounded by cuff of lymphocytes
  • Focal area of granulomatous inflammation
  • H&E stain: Epithelioid cells have pale granular cytoplasm with indistinct boundaries

  • Langhan’s: Giant 🡪 epithelioid cells that fuse 🡪 large mass of cytoplasm with >{{c1::20}} nuclei arranged in periphery or haphazardly
  • {{c1::}}

  • Immune Granulomas 🡪 Disease
  • Caused by insoluble particles that are capable of inducing a cell-mediated immune response
  • Macrophages are transformed into epithelioid cells and multinucleate {{c1::giant}} cells
  • Examples:
  • Crohn’s disease (autoimmune/intestinal bacteria) 🡪 {{c1::granulomatous}} element distinguishes it from ulcerative colitis
  • Give 2/4 others
    • {{c1::
    • TB (myco tuberc) 🡪 central caseous necrosis 
    • Leprosy (myco leprae)
    • Syphilis (treponema pallidum)
    • Sarcoidosis (unknown) 🡪 lung and lymph nodes 
      • }}
  • Foreign Body Granulomas
  • Epithelioid and giant cells are opposed to the surface and encompass the foreign body
  • Poorly organised
  • Main cytokine 🡪 {{c1::MCP1}} (released by monocyte)
  • Foreign body usually found in centre of granuloma
  • Talc/splinter/suture
  • Metal/dust 🡪 silicosis

• Systemic effects of Inflammation
  • Fever 🡪 by 1-4 degree
  • Elevated conc of acute-phase proteins
  • Leucocytosis ({{c1::15-20,000}} cells/mL)
  • Increased pulse and bp, rigors, chills, malaise
  • Sepsis
  • Sepsis 
  • Bacteraemia/sepsis 🡪 pathogens gain access to vascular circulation
  • Tissue-resident {{c1::macrophages}} must then prevent overwhelming infection 🡪 phagocytic cells of liver, spleen and bone marrow
  • {{c1::Heart}} valves, meninges, kidneys, joints are favoured sited of implantation for blood-borne organisms
  • Septic Shock
  • Systemic vaso{{c1::dilation}} 🡪 tissue hyp{{c1::o}}perfusion and haemodynamic {{c1::shock}}
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) 🡪 multiple thrombi in circulation and fibrin split products
  • {{c1::Hypotension due to release of NO}}
  • Metabolic abnormalities 🡪 {{c1::insulin}} resistance and {{c1::hyperglycaemia}} --. Multi organ failure

{{c1::Hematopoiesis}} is a term describing the formation and development of blood cells.

Hematopoiesis begins as early as the {{c1::19th}} day after fertilization in the {{c1::yolk sac of the embryo}}
-Only {{c1::erythrocytes}} are made
-The RBCs contain unique fetal{{c1::hemoglobins}}
-At about 6 weeks of gestation, yolk sac production of erythrocytes decreases and production of RBCs in the human embryo itself begins.

-The fetal {{c1::liver}} becomes the chief site of blood cell production
-The {{c1::spleen, kidney, thymus, and lymph nodes}} (4) serve as minor sites of blood cell production
-the bone marrow becomes the primary site of hematopoiesis at about {{c1::6 months of gestation}} and continues throughout life.
-When the bone marrow becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis, leukocyte and thrombocyte production become more prominent.

-Hematopoiesis in the bone marrow is called {{c1::medullary haematopoiesis}}
-Hematopoiesis in areas other then the bone marrow is called {{c1::extramedullary hematopoiesis}}

-Extramedullary hematopoiesis may occur in fetal hematopoietic tissue (liver and spleen) of an adult when the bone marrow cannot meet the physiologic needs of the tissues.  This can lead to hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly (increase in size of the liver and/or spleen because of increased functions in the organs).
The mononuclear phagocytic system also called reticular endothelial system, RES) is involved in {{c1::cellular destruction}} and it includes (3)

-Circulating blood monocytes
-Fixed macrophages in the bone marrow, liver, spleen, and lymph nodes
-Free macrophages
¢These cells are involved in:
Engulfing particulate matter
Processing of antigens for lymphocyte presentation
Removal of damaged or senescent (aged) cells

{{c1::Spleen}} – contains the largest collection of lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes in the body.
Name its 3 functions

The spleen functions in:
¢Filtering and destruction of senescent (aged) or damaged RBCS – also called culling
¢Removal of particles (are found in some types of anemia) from RBC membranes – also called pitting – this causes a decrease in the surface to volume ratio of the RBC resulting in the formation of spherocytes (more on this later)
¢Enforcing close contact of blood borne antigens with lymphocytes and phagocytic cells – this is more important in children particularly in protection of the host from infections due to enveloped organisms

-Sequestering {{c1::1/3}} of the platlet mass – in massive splenomegaly this can lead to peripheral {{c1::thrombocytopenia (decrease in platlets in the peripheral blood)}}

-After a {{c1::splenectomy (removal of the spleen)}}, RBC inclusions and abnormal RBC shapes are seen.  Culling is taken over by the {{c1::liver}} which is less effective in performing all of the {{c1::splenic}} functions

{{c1::Hypersplenism (splenomegaly)}} – in a number of conditions the spleen may become enlarged and through an exaggeration of its normal functions of filtering, and destruction and sequestering, it may cause {{c1::anemia (may be caused by decreased RBCs)}}, {{c1::leukopenia (decreased WBCs)}}, or {{c1::thrombocytopenia}} or combinations of these cytopenias.  When all three cell types are decreased this is called pancytopenia.

There are two types of hypersplenism:

-Primary – no underlying disease has been identified
-Secondary – caused by an underlying disorder such as:
Inflammatory diseases
Infectious diseases
Blood disorders that cause compensatory or workload hypertrophy of the organ such as:
  Abnormal blood cells, antibody coated blood cells, hereditary spherocytosis, idiopathic throbocytopenic purpura (ITP)
The effects of these are relieved by splenectomy

{{c1::Ischaemia}}:restriction in blood supply (from either reduced arterial flow or reduced venous drainage) which causes oxygen deprivation and results in tissue damage.

{{c1::Infarction}}: An area of ischaemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either the arterial supply or the venous drainage in a particular tissue. 

Vast majority of infarcts due to thrombotic /embolic events, almost all due to {{c1::arterial}} occlusion

•{{c1::Venous thrombosis}} more often induces venous obstruction and congestion rather than infarction.
What are the exceptions?

Exception: organs with a single venous outflow channel,
e.g. testis or ovary

Which is white vs. red infarct?
A With venous occlusions (testis, ovary).

B In loose tissues such as lung which allow blood to collect in the infarcted zone.

C Occur with arterial occlusions or in solid organs (e.g. heart, spleen, kidney) where the solidity of the tissue limits the amount of haemorrhage that can seep into the area of ischaemic necrosis from adjoining capillary beds.

D In tissues with dual circulations (e.g. lung, liver) allowing flow of blood from the unobstructed vessel into the necrotic zone (but not enough perfusion to restore the ischaemic tissues).

Phospholipids: Complex lipids, resembling triglycerides, but containing {{c1::phosphate}} and a {{c1::nitrogenous base}}  in place of one fatty acid
Which part is hydrophilic?

•Important components of cell membranes and lipoproteins, maintaining the solubility of triglycerides and cholesterol

The nitrogen part is hydrophilic

Lipoproteins
•Plasma lipids are derived from food or are synthesized in the body
•As lipids are fairly insoluble in water they are carried in body fluids as soluble protein complexes known as lipoproteins
•They have a core of insoluble {{c1::cholesterol esters}} and {{c1::triglycerides}} surrounded by proteins, phospholipids and free cholesterol with their {{c1::water}} soluble groups facing outwards.

Classified by their {{c1::density}} which correlates directly with their {{c1::protein}} concentration and inversely with their {{c1::size}}

What do Chylomicrons do?
What do VLDLs do?

•Chylomicrons transport exogenous lipid from the intestine to all cells

•VLDL (very low density lipoprotein) transports endogenous lipid from the liver to cells

{{c1::HDL }}: involved in the transport of cholesterol from the cells to the liver, the main protein is apoA

{{c1::LDL}} formed from VLDL, transports cholesterol to cells, the main protein is apoB

{{c1::Atherosclerosis}}: Disease of arteries, resulting in the formation of multiple plaques (AKA {{c1::atheromas}}) within the arteries

Plaques
•pathological accumulation of cells or cell debris, which contain lipids (cholesterol & fatty acids), {{c1::calcium}} & fibrous connective tissue within the walls of arteries
•The debris accumulates between the endothelium and the {{c1::smooth muscle wall (media)}}

{{c1::Atheromas}} reduce blood flow leading to:
•{{c1::Coronary}} Artery Disease
•{{c1::Cerebrovascular}} Disease
{{c1::Peripheral}} Vascular Disease

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Minor endothelial damage, Name 4 causes {{c1::(turbulence, relative anoxia, hypertension, oxidation or glycation)}}
•{{c1::LDL}} particles cross the damaged endothelium
•Circulating monocytes attracted by the damaged endothelium & enter the {{c1::subendothelial}} space.
•LDL particles in the artery wall are {{c1::oxidised}} by oxygen free radicals name 4 sources {{c1::(present in cigarette smoke, formed during glycation reactions, generated by macrophages deliberately to kill bacteria or leaking from various oxidative pathways)}}
•Oxidised LDL is taken up rapidly by macrophages (AKA {{c1::foam cells}})
Schema of Atherogenesis

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Collagen elaborated by {{c1::fibroblasts}} comes to overlie the foam cells, which undergo necrosis or apoptosis
•This results in the formation of a pool of extracellular {{c1::cholesterol}} trapped beneath a {{c1::fibrous}} cap.
•At the shoulder of the {{c1::atheromatous}} lesion active foam cell formation continues & the lesion advances across the inner surface of the artery.
•Plaques can either obstruct blood flow resulting in ischaemia to the peripheral tissue or rupture with thrombus formation at the site of {{c1::the cap}} leading to {{c1::peripheral}} infarction.

{{c1::Endocrine}}

--------------------------------
A. Characterised by progressive cardiac dilatation and contractile (systolic) dysfunction, usually with concomitant hypertrophy. 
Gross: Any coronary artery stenosis present may be insufficient to explain the degree of cardiac abnormality.

HCM: Pathogenesis
¡Caused by mutations in any one of several genes that encode {{c1::sarcomeric}} proteins (>400 mutations in 9 different genes)

¡Most common mutation is in the gene encoding {{c1::β-myosin heavy}} chain

¡Basic physiologic abnormality is reduced {{c1::stroke}} volume due to impaired diastolic {{c1::filling}} which results from reduced {{c1::chamber}} size and {{c1::compliance}} of the massively hypertrophied LV

Response to Injury theory – Atherosclerosis is a chronic {{c1::inflammatory}} response of the arterial wall initiated by some form of injury to the vessel wall

Steps
{{c1::Endothelial}} cell injury 
-> lead to {{c1::endothelial}} dysfunction 
->Monocytes (CD{{c1::8}}, {{c1::CD4}}) adhere to abnormal endothelium (adhesion molecules) & migrate into vessel wall.
->Secrete {{c1::Cytokines}} (Growth factors) 
->Attract Smooth muscle cells & Activate {{c1::macrophages}}


•Early lesion = {{c1::Fatty Streak}}
•Advanced lesion = {{c1::Fibrous Plaque}}

Fatty Streaks
•Confined to {{c1::intima}}
•Composed of lipid filled {{c1::foam}} cells.
•Flat, no blood flow disturbance.
•Multiple 1mm yellow spots, coalesce into streaks >1cm


Steps
Fatty Streaks enlarge and Disrupt Endothelial Surface
->Platelets {{c1::adhere}}
->Platelets release {{c1::PDGF}}
->More Smooth Muscle {{c1::Proliferation}}

Injured Endothelial Cells and Macrophages      Produce {{c1::Free Radicals}}
 ->Oxidise {{c1::LDL}} 
        - {{c1::Chemotactic}} for Monocytes
        - Stimulates release of {{c1::growth factors}}  
        - Neutralised by Antioxidants
-{{c1::collagen}} synthesis
Oxidised LDL: More Atherogenic

{{c1::Intimal}} plaque:Central aggregation of {{c1::foam}} cells, some of which have died and released lipid , surrounded by smooth muscle cells, with connective tissue on {{c1::intimal}} aspect

Plaques can undergo disruption, with superimposed {{c1::thrombus}}, rupture ---  known as complicated (vulnerable) plaque leads to {{c1::MI}}, {{c1::stroke}}

•> 2 months - scar

Aortic Dissection
•Dissection of blood along layers of {{c1::aortic media}}
•Formation of blood-filled {{c1::false}} lumen
•Rupture leads to massive haemorrhage
•3 cases per 100,000 per year
•20% die before reaching hospital; 30% die during hospital admission
•Peak frequency 0800h-0900h and in winter

Pathophysiology
•Most (>80%) develop without pre-existing thoracic aortic aneurysm
•Risk factors: hypertension, old age, atherosclerosis, previous cardiovascular surgery, {{c1::Marfan}}’s syndrome, {{c1::Ehlers-Danlos type IV}} (type), {{c1::Turner}}’s syndrome (webbed neck), {{c1::bicuspid}} aortic valve (1% of population), {{c1::Takayasu}}’s arteritis, familial (19%), pregnancy
•Marfan’s syndrome: mutations in gene for {{c1::fibrillin 1}}

Tuberculosis 
§Tuberculosis (TB) is the world's leading infectious killer of young and middle-aged adults, causing 26 percent of avoidable deaths in the developing world .

§TB is a highly infectious airborne disease caused by {{c1::Mycobacterium tuberculosis}} .
§Crowded homes and congregate settings (such as shelters, hospitals, and prisons) tend to foster transmission

§Although pulmonary TB is the most common form, the disease can affect virtually any organ (for example, lymph nodes,bones, brain, and genitals). 

§Pulmonary TB is caused by inhalation of air-droplet from infected patient. From the primary lesion in the lung through blood stream it can spread to all organs in the body

-Gastrointestinal TB is caused by drinking unpasteurized milk contaminated by {{c1::mycobacteria bovis}}. This is very rare in developed countries

COPD: is a disease state characterised by decreased airflow that is not {{c1::fully reversible}}.

It encompasses two clinical entities:
-{{c1::Chronic bronchitis}} – large airway inflammation
-{{c1::Emphysema}} – disease of distal airways

-Smokers have a {{c1::20-25}}% chance of developing COPD.

Risk Factors for COPD
Host factors
-Disordered lung development
-Asthma and airway hyper-responsiveness
-{{c1::Alpha-1-antitrypsin}} deficiency

Environmental factors
-Tobacco smoke
-Air pollution
-Occupational dusts/chemicals
-Childhood infections
-Lower socioeconomic status

Diagnosis of COPD
-Consider in patients with cough, sputum production, or dyspnoea +/- risk factors.

-Confirmed by {{c1::spirometry}}.

-FEV1/FVC <{{c1::70}}% (normal 70-80%) + post-bronchodilator FEV1 <{{c1::80}}% of predicted value.

-Abnormal flow-volume loop.

What's FVC? {{c1::Forced vital capacity (FVC) is the total amount of air exhaled during the FEV test.}}
What is the Classification of Severity based on? {{c1::FEV1 of predicted value}}

Respiratory Failure

-Results when gas exchange is inadequate, resulting in hypoxia, with PaO2 <{{c1::8}}kPa.

-Type 1: Hypoxia with {{c1::normal/low PaCO2}}.
lGive 1 cause {{c1::Caused by ventilation/perfusion mismatch, e.g., life-threatening asthma; emphysema.}}

-Type 2: Hypoxia with {{c1::hypercapnia (PaCO2 >6.5kPa).}}
- 1 cause? {{c1::
Caused by alveolar hypoventilation, e.g., chronic bronchitis.
}}


Why Oxygen therapy must be controlled in type 2?
-{{c1::Oxygen therapy must be controlled in type 2 respiratory failure, due to the risk of further hypercapnia if the hypoxic drive to ventilation is abolished by excessive oxygen.}}

Give the differences between them.

Community-acquired (CAP): Acute infection of lung tissue in patient who acquired it in the community or within 48 hours of hospitalisation

Hospital-acquired (HAP) ¢ Acute infection of lung tissue in a patient is in hospital, after 48 hours of hospitalisation

Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) acute infection of lung tissue that develops in a patient who is intubated and ventilated in the ICU

Aspiration pneumonia ¢ Acute infection of lung tissue in a patient who has a risk of aspirating. such as altered mental state, post stroke (impaired swallow), alcoholism, seizure disorder etc

Cellular Adaptations: Reversible changes in size, number, phenotype, metabolic activity, or functions of cells in response to change in their environment

Give 2 types. 
{{c1::
1- physiologic (response to normal stimulation by hormones or endogenous chemical mediators) 
2- pathologic (response to stresses to escape injury)
}}

Give 4 forms {{c1::hypertrophy, hyperplasia, atrophy, metaplasia}}

Hypertrophy
Give Definition
 {{c1::increase in the size of cells > increase in the size of the organ (with increased functional capacity) ie No new cells, just larger cells}}

Give 2 physiologic causes.
{{c1::
-Increased functional demand Skeletal muscles heart
-Specitic hormonal stimulation Pregnant uterus (estrogen stimulates s.m. hypertrophy & hyperplasia)
}}

Give 3 pathologic types and causes.
{{c1::
Adaptive hypertrophy (wall of hollow muscular organs) 
-Stomach in case of pyloric obstruction 
-Left ventricle in case of aortic valve disease or hypertension 
-Urinary bladder in case of urethral stricture

Compensatory hypertrophy: In paired organs as in kidney
-when one kidney is absent or removed surgically, the other kidney is enlarged in size

Hormonal hypertrophy: eg: excessive growth hormone leads to gigantism or acromegaly
}}

Atrophy
Give Definition {{c1::shrinkage in the size of cell by loss of cell substance. When a sufficient number of cells involved, the entire tissue/organ diminishes in size.}}

Give 3 Physiological causes.
{{c1::
-Atrophy of thymus gland after puberty & thyroglossal duct after birth (involution) 
-Decreased workload “disuse”: immobilized limb to permit healing of fracture 
-Loss of hormone stimulation: atrophy of ovaries & uterus after menopause
}}

Give 2 Pathological causes.
{{c1::
-Loss of innervation. 
-Starvation (lack of food & its absorption) & malnutrition.
}}

Hyperplasia
Define. {{c1::increase in the number of cells -> increase in the size of the organ.}}

It may occur with hypertrophy & often in response to the same stimull.

Give 2 physiologic causes.
{{c1::
-Hormonal (glandular epithelium of female breast at puberty & pregnancy) 
-Compensatory (when a portion of tissue is resected or diseased, eg. Liver)
}}

Give 2 Pathologic causes.
{{c1::
Excessive hormonal or growth factor stimulation
-Endometrial hyperplasia: due to loss of balance between estrogen & progesterone hormones. This results In abnormal menstrual bleeding
-Thyroid gland: due to increased thyroid Stimulating hormone (TSH) in thyrotoxicosis. 
- Adrenal gland: due to adreno-corticotropic hormone (ACTH) in Cushing’s syndrome.

Hyperplasia is an important response of CT cells in wound healing. Growth factors are produced by WBCs responding to injury & by cells in ECM.

Hyperplasia due to viral infection. e.g.. HPV that causes skin warts & squamous cell papilloma of m.m. Here, growth factors may be produced by virus or by infected cells.
}}

How does it Differ From Neoplasia?
{{c1::
It occurs in tissue made up of labile or stable cells that have the power of regeneration under normal or pathologic conditions. 
• Occurs in response to a stimulus, disappears when the stimulus when it is removed. 
• Usually performs a function. 
• It is a reversible non-neoplastic process.
}}

Metaplasia
• Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one {{c1::differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal)}} is replaced by another cell type. 
• Adaptive substitution of cells that are sensitive to stress by cell types better able to withstand the adverse environment. 
• The most common epithelial metaplasia is {{c1::COLUMNAR-> SQUAMOUS}}: respiratory tract in response to chronic irritation.

Other common metaplasia
– COLUMNAR -> SQUAMOUS (Respiratory tract) 
– SQUAMOUS -> COLUMNAR (Barrets esophagus) 
– FIBROUS -> BONE

Dysplasia
Literally means disordered growth- denotes a loss of architectural organization and a loss of cell uniformity in {{c1::epithelium}}

• Ranges from mild dysplasia to severe ({{c1::carcinoma in situ}}) 
• No invasion of {{c1::basement membrane}}. 

• {{c1::Pleomorphism}} of cells (variation in size and shape). 
• {{c1::Hyperchromatic}} nuclei with increased nucleocytoplasmic ratio and increased mitotic activity. 
• Loss of {{c1::polarity (orientation)}} of cells. 
• Mild and moderate degrees of dysplasia are reversible when the evoking stimulus is removed. However, severe degree is considered pre-invasive malignancy.

• Partial loss of differentiation. 
• Disordered maturation with impaired function. 
• It represents reaction to underlying inflammation or to chronic irritation.

{{c1::Neoplasm}}: clonal neoplastic cells surrounded by supporting stroma: blood vessels, connective tissue and inflammatory cells

1) Benign: localized and amenable to surgical removal; patient usually survives 
2) Malignant: invasive tumor capable of destroying structures and spread to distant sites (metastasis); may result in early death of the patient

Limitless replicative potential

Rheumatoid Arthritis
uInflammatory Disease that Affects Joints
uinflammatory synovitis
uDestruction of articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints
uExtra-articular lesion can be found in the skin, heart, blood vessels, and lungs
uIe Systemic
uCaused by autoimmune {{c1::CD4+ T}} cell activation
u{{c1::IFN gamma}} (from Th1 cells) activate {{c1::macrophages}}
uIL-17 from Th17 cells recruits neutrophils and monocytes,
u{{c1::TNF}}, IL-1 from macrophages mediates a lot of the damaging effects

Rheumatoid Arthritis-Case study
u7 months ago a 48-year old hairdresser experienced morning stiffness in both hands and increasing difficulty standing for long periods at work or at home due to foot and ankle pain. ibuprofen 800mg 3 times daily improved symptoms.
u3 months she noticed pain in her right and left shoulders when drying client’s hair. Additionally she felt extremely tired and lacked energy for energy for usual activities. Ibuprofen was no longer effective.
uAdditionally she reported experiencing intermittent fever
uShe visited her GP who ordered a series of tests.
u The blood tests revealed positive rheumatoid factor, CCP antibodies, elevated ESR and C-reactive protein.

{{c1::Inflammation is occuring}}

Sjogren’s Syndrome 
uA 52-year old woman presented with a painful enlarged parotid gland. 
uShe reported that three months earlier she had presented with an enlarged parotid gland, accompanied by severe pain on the opposite side, fever and had been treated for mumps. 
uWhen questioned about dryness the patient said that she experiences oral dryness on a daily basis for the past 5 years and had been tested for diabetes (negative) due to the frequent dryness/thirst.
uThe patient also reported that she experienced dry and gritty eyes, and was prone to muscular pains and painful joints. 
uSchirmer's test was performed. The test was markedly abnormal as only 3.0mm of the filter strip in the right eye and 1.0mm of that in the left eye became wet.

Making a Tissue Diagnosis
•A tissue diagnosis is required before treatment instituted for almost all cancers
•Different approaches to getting tissue depend on the site of the lesion

{{c1::Punch}} biopsy  - suitable for superficial sites e.g. skin   lesion
•{{c1::Needle core}} biopsy – for deeper lesions; can be performed with or without radiological guidance. Former can be done for palpable lesion in accessible site e.g. Obvious breast lump 
{{c1::Fine needle aspirate/washings}} - used for head & neck lumps, pleura, lung, ascites, biliary brushings
{{c1::Excisional}} biopsy e.g. for skin lesions , lymph nodes, or lesions that are indeterminate on core biopsy
{{c1::Frozen}} section Rarely used usually only for testicular mass, renal tumours, met to node
{{c1::Resection}} - Sometimes diagnosis is made at definitive resection e.g. kidney, thyroid

SVCS may develop quickly and block your breathing completely. If so, you might need a machine to help you breathe until doctors treat the blockage. It is more common for SVCS to develop slowly. A paraneoplastic syndrome is a syndrome  that is the consequence of cancer in the body, specifically due to the production of chemical signaling molecules (such as hormones ) by tumor cells or by an immune response against the tumor. Unlike a mass effect, it is not due to the local presence of cancer cells.

BRAF mutations
•V600E-mutated tumors showed an aggressive histotype characterized by {{c1::micropapillary}} features in 80% of patients and were significantly associated with shorter disease-free and overall survival rates
•The B-Raf proto-oncoprotein (BRAF) is a {{c1::serine/threonine}} kinase that regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, angiogenesis, and cell death. It functions {{c1::down}}stream of RAS and signals through the MAPK/ERK pathway

KRAS
No therapies for targeting KRAS mutations in cancer have been approved. The KRAS p.G12C mutation occurs in 13% of non–small-cell lung cancers and in 1 to 3% of colorectal cancers and other cancers. {{c1::Sotorasib}} is a small molecule that selectively and irreversibly targets KRASG12C.

Several novel covalent direct inhibitors targeting KRASG12C with similar covalent binding mechanisms are now in clinical trials. Both AMG 510 from Amgen and MRTX849 from Mirati Therapeutics covalently binds to KRASG12C at the {{c1::cysteine}} at residue 12, keeping KRASG12C in its inactive GDP-bound state and inhibiting KRAS-dependent signaling

•Formation of the amyloid relies on polymerisation of {{c1::fibrils}} from an unstable intermediate state

3-Hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme regulating cholesterol biosynthesis. The enzyme is downregulated by excess cholesterol in the cell.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious syndrome due to a direct or indirect muscle injury. It results from the death of muscle fibers and release of their contents into the bloodstream. This can lead to serious complications such as renal (kidney) failure. This means the kidneys cannot remove waste and concentrated urine.

Myopathy is a general term referring to any disease that affects the muscles that control voluntary movement in the body. Patients experience muscle weakness due to a dysfunction of the muscle fibers.
