Bacterial Chemotherapy
• Chemotherapeutic drugs should be {{c1::toxic}} to invading organisms but non-toxic to humans. Selective toxicity (Most cases, relative, rather than absolute). 

• Microbiota in GIT, lungs and vaginal tracts. 

• Drugs should target unique genetic or biochemical pathways to pathogens. 

• Drugs should be {{c1::selective}} to target protein isoforms unique to the pathogen without affecting human forms. 

• Drugs should target {{c1::metabolic}} requirements that are specific to the pathogen.

Give definitions for these
• Anti-bacterial (anti-microbial) drugs 
{{c1::
– Interfere with the growth of microbes within a host 
– May be synthetic or derived from a living organism 
}}

• Antibiotic 
{{c1::
– Substance produced by a microbe that, in small amounts, inhibits another microbe 
– A subclass of antibacterial drug 
}}

• Bacteriostatic 
{{c1::
– Stops growth/proliferation but does not kill bacteria
– Host defence required to defeat infection
}} 

• Bactericidal 
{{c1::– Kills bacteria}}

Chemotherapy
A. Narrow spectrum: Acting only on a single or limited group of microorganisms, e.g. isoniazid against mycobacteria 
B. Extended spectrum: Active against Gram-negative e.g. ampicillin 
C. Broad spectrum: Affect a wide variety of microbial species. Can drastically alter normal bacterial flora and can precipitate a superinfection e.g. candida (normally kept in check by other microorganisms) with {{c1::tetracycline}} and {{c1::chloramphenicol}}

• Class I reactions: that use utilise glucose and other carbon sources are used to produce {{c1::ATP}} and simple molecules. 
• Not promising targets because humans and bacteria use similar mechanisms to obtain energy from glucose and even if glucose is blocked other sources of carbon can be used by bacteria. 

• Class II reactions: pathways utilising energy and class I compounds to make {{c1::small molecules (e.g. nucleotides)}}. Agents that interfere with {{c1::folate synthesis}} can be used. 

• Class III reactions: pathways that convert small molecules into macromolecules such as {{c1::proteins, nucleic acids and peptidoglycan}}. Agents that interfere with protein synthesis, e.g. {{c1::RNA polymerase and DNA gyrase}}. Agents that target formed cell structures e.g. cell membrane.

Peptidoglycan Synthesis 
• Bacterial cell walls contain peptidoglycan, which is not in eukaryotic cells. 
• In Gram negative bacteria, it is a single layer thick but in Gram positive bacteria it can be up to 40 layers thick. 
• Each layer consists of multiple backbones of alternating {{c1::N-acetylglucosamine}} (NAG) and Nacetylmuramic acid (NAM) 
• NAM residues are cross-linked together via an {{c1::interpeptide}} bridge.


• Plasma membrane of bacterial cells is similar to that in eukaryotes 
- phospholipid bilayer in which proteins are embedded. 

• Certain antibacterial drugs act as detergents by disrupting the phospholipid components of the membrane and kill the cells. 

• Polymixins are {{c1::cat}}ionic peptide antibiotics that contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic groups

Nucleic Acid Synthesis
• Inhibiting the synthesis of nucleotides – class {{c1::II}} reactions.
 
• {{c1::Folate}} is required for DNA synthesis in bacteria, some antibacterials interfere with this pathway e.g. Sulphonamides, trimethoprim. 

• Altering the base-pairing properties of the template, and intercalate with DNA, increase distance between base pairs and cause a {{c1::frameshift}} mutation e.g. 
Acridines – proflavine & acriflavine. 

• Direct effects on DNA itself: alkylating agents affect the formation of covalent bonds with bases in DNA and prevent replication e.g. Nitrosureas, mitomycin, bleomycin. 

• Tend to be used in cancer chemotherapy.

DNA as a drug target 
• Inhibiting DNA polymerase e.g. Aciclovir.

• Inhibiting RNA polymerase e.g. Actinomycin D, rifampicin. 

• Inhibiting DNA gyrase e.g. the fluoroquinolones - ciprofloxacin. 

• Initiation of DNA synthesis requires the {{c1::separation}} of the strands. 

• The replication process induces a positive supercoil which is relaxed by DNA {{c1::gyrase/topoisomerase II}}.

Protein Synthesis Inhibitors 
• Eukaryotic and prokaryotic ribosomes are different and this provides the basis for selective antimicrobial action. • 

The bacterial ribosome consists of a {{c1::50}}S and a {{c1::30}}S subunit to give a {{c1::70}}S complete ribosome. 

• The eukaryotic ribosome consists of a {{c1::60}}S and a {{c1::40}}S subunit to give a {{c1::80}}S complete ribosome. 

• To initiate bacterial translation mRNA must bind to the {{c1::30}}S subunit first and then bind the {{c1::50}}S. 

• The ribosome has 3 binding sites for tRNA termed {{c1::E, P and A.}}

Antibacterial drug Resistance
• {{c1::One}} in 10 patients entering a European hospital will develop an infection caused by drug-resistant microbes such as the hospital super bug, MRSA. 

• {{c1::50}}% of Staphylococci resistant to penicillin, methicillin, tetracycline, & erythromycin. 

• Enterococcus faecium – penicillin resistance in 1983. 

• {{c1::Streptococcus}} pneumoniae – penicillin resistance 1967. 

• {{c1::Mycobacterium}} tuberculosis – resistance to isoniazid, rifampin.

Drug Resistance
Give 3 MoA
{{c1::
• Mutation in a drug binding site, lowering the affinity of the interaction 

•Genes encoding for enzymes that degrade antibacterial agents 

-efflux pump
}}

• Chromosomal determinants: mutations – 1 cell in 10^7 mutated, much higher than us

• Extrachromosomal plasmids – replicate independently R plasmids.

Give 3 methods of gene transfer
{{c1::}}

Folate Synthesis Pathway
• Folate synthesis occurs in bacteria. 

• Mammals cannot synthesise so must obtain folate from diet. 

• {{c1::p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA)}} required to make folate. 

• Folate required for {{c1::DNA}} synthesis. 

• Selectivity of drugs that interfere with folate synthesis or action 

• Target {{c1::dihydropteroate}} synthetase 

• Sulphonamides - structural analogues of {{c1::PABA}} & competitive inhibitors 

• Bacteriostatic not bactericidal – suppress the division of cells.


Trimethoprim 
• Resembles {{c1::pteridine}} ring of folate 
• Targets {{c1::dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) }}
Is it active in human(mammal) or bacterial cells?
{{c1::• active against mammalian enzyme but requires much higher concentrations than in bacteria
 }}

Methotrexate: Used to treat cancer and rheumatoid arthritis, not antibacterial, due to folate as it requires active uptake by cells.

Sulphonamides
• Most sulphonamides are given orally and are well absorbed (except {{c1::sulfasalazine}}). 

• Widely distributed and {{c1::can}} cross BBB and placental barrier. 

• Metabolised mainly in the {{c1::liver}} and the major metabolite is the acetylated form that lacks antibacterial effects. 

• {{c1::Hepatitis}}, hypersensitivity reactions and renal failure due to interstitial nephritis

Uses
-Widespread supha drug resistnace 
– For infected burns (topically). 
– Sulfasalazine used for IBD

Trimethoprim 
• Trimethoprim is absorbed well orally and widely distributed. 

• Reaches high concentrations in the kidney, lungs and {{c1::can}} cross BBB . 

• Trimethoprim is a weak {{c1::base}} and its elimination increases with decreasing urinary pH. 

• Can lead to folate deficiency in people with resultant {{c1::megaloblastic}} anaemia – related to pharmacological action.

Uses
– Urinary tract infections. 
– Respiratory tract infections. 
– STIs 
– chlamydia.

Peptidoglycan Synthesis

These are mixed up order without drug names, fix it.

• {{c1::Cycloserine}} is a structural analogue of Dalanine and prevents the addition of the terminal alanine residues to the side chain on NAM by competitive inhibition. 

• {{c1::Penicillins, cephalosporins and other βlactams}} inhibit the final transpeptidation and prevent formation of crosslinks.

• {{c1::Bacitracin}} interferes with the regeneration of the lipid carrier by blocking its dephosphorylation. 

• {{c1::Vancomycin}} inhibits the release of the building block unit from the carrier thereby preventing the addition to the growing end of the peptidoglycan.

β-lactam antibiotics
• Include penicillins, cephalosporins, carbpenems and monobactams 

• All β-lactam antibiotics interfere with the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall {{c1::peptidoglycan}}. 

• Penicillins attach to penicillin-binding proteins on bacteria, inhibit the transpeptidation enzyme that {{c1::crosslinks}} peptide chains in the backbone. 

• First penicillins were naturally occurring benzylpenicillin (penicillin G) as well as phenoxymethylpenicillin (penicillin V). 

Which one is the common drug of choice?
{{c1::• Penicillin G is active against a wide range of organisms and is the drug of first choice for many infections.}}

• Over 20 semisynthetic penicillins with different R group substitutions have been generated. 

• While penicillins are very effective, they can be degraded by bacterial {{c1::amidases}} and β-lactamases 

• β-lactamase resistant penicillins –(2) {{c1::methicillin, flucloxacillin. }}

• Broad-spectrum penicillins – ampicillin, amoxicillin

• Administration: (3) {{c1::Intravenous, intramuscular and intrathecal (less common) injections are used. }}

• PK: Widely distributed in bodily fluids (including bile, saliva and milk) and pass into joints, pleural, pericardial cavities, across the placenta and the BBB only if {{c1::it is inflamed}}.

• Do not enter mammalian cells as they are {{c1::lipid insoluble}}. 

• Elimination of most penicillins is mainly {{c1::renal (by tubular secretion)}} and occurs rapidly – relatively short half life. 

• Side-effects: include hypersensitivity reactions caused by the degradation products, which combine with host protein to become antigenic. 

• Skin rashes and fever are common in some people, with rare anaphylactic shock and alteration of the gut microbiota (GI disturbances).

Clinical Applications 
• Benzylpenicillin for bacterial meningitis (Streptococcus {{c1::pneumoniae}}), endocarditis (Enterococcus {{c1::faecalis}}) and skin and tissue infections (Streptococcus pyogenes/Staphylococcus aureus). 

• Flucloxacillin for bone and joint infections (Staphylococcus {{c1::aureus}}). 

• Amoxicillin for bronchitis (mixed infections), pneumonia, gonorrhoea and urinary tract infections (Escherichia coli).

Cephalosporins
• Cephalosporins were first isolated from Cephalosporium fungus and are chemically related to β-lactams. 

• Semi-synthetic broad spectrum cephalosporins have been produced by addition at R1 and R2 

• {{c1::Water}} soluble and acid stable but vary in susceptibility to βlactamases 

• First (e.g. cefadroxil), second (e.g. cefaclor) and third ({{c1::cefotaxime}}) generations. Over 70 clinical agents have been developed 

• Administration: Most are given parenterally but some are given orally. 

• PK: Widely distributed and {{c1::some}} cross the BBB, excretion is mostly via kidney (tubular secretion) but some members via {{c1::bile}}. 

• Side effects: Hypersensitivity reactions as well as {{c1::nephro}}toxicity.

Uses 
• Septicaemia – cefuroxime & cefotaxime. 
• Pneumonia 
• Meningitis – ceftraxone & cefotaxime. 
• Urinary tract infections – cefaclor. 
• Sinusitis – cefadroxil. 
• Biliary tract infection

Carbapenams 
• Acts in the same way as other β-lactams, broad spectrum antibacterial activity e.g. {{c1::imipenam}}. 
• Used with {{c1::cilistatin}} to block its breakdown with {{c1::renal}} enzymes. 
• Side effects: similar to other β-lactams with {{c1::neuro}}toxicity at high conc.

Monobactams: 
• Main member is {{c1::atreonam}} is resistant to β-lactamases and effective only against Gram {{c1::–ve}} {{c1::}}aerobic bacteria.

Glycopeptides: 
• Such as {{c1::vancomycin}} act by inhibiting the release of the building block unit from the lipid carrier. 
• Not orally absorbed, given for GI infection or i.v. 
• Used in resistant bacteria, but growing rate of {{c1::resistance to vancomycin}} is limiting its use 
• Side effects: include fever, rashes, ototoxicity and {{c1::nephro}}toxicity.

What is ototoxicity?
{{c1::Ototoxicity is the property of being toxic to the ear (oto-), specifically the cochlea or auditory nerve and sometimes the vestibular system, for example, as a side effect of a drug. The effects of ototoxicity can be reversible and temporary, or irreversible and permanent.}}

Polymixins
• Polymixin B and colistin/polymixin E are the main members in use. 

• MOA: {{c1::Cat}}ionic detergent properties and act by disrupting the outer cell membrane. 

• Rapid selective bactericidal action against Gram {{c1::–ve}} {{c1::bacilli }}

• PK: Not absorbed from the GI tract. 

• Side effects: {{c1::Neuro}}toxicity and {{c1::nephro}}toxicity. 

• Clinical use: is restricted to {{c1::topical}} treatment of ear, eye or skin infections and for gut sterilization.

Quinolones and fluoroquinolones
• Bactericidal inhibit bacterial DNA synthetic enzymes {{c1::topoisomerase II (a DNA gyrase)}} responsible for supercoiling of DNA 

• The most commonly used are {{c1::ciprofloxacin}} and {{c1::levofloxacin}}, {{c1::-floxacin}}

• {{c1::Ciprofloxacin}} is a broad spectrum antibiotic effective against Gram +ve & -ve bacteria including those resistant to penicillins. 

• PK: Well absorbed orally but accumulate in the kidney and {{c1::lungs}} and {{c1::most}} cross the BBB. 

• Metabolised by CYP450 enzymes in the liver and excreted by kidney. 

• Interactions with other drugs due to inhibition of P450 ({{c1::theophylline}} toxicity). 

• Side effects: GI disorders and rashes

Uses of fluoroquinolones 
• Urinary tract infections – norfloxacin & ofloxacin. 
• Respiratory infection Pseudomonas aeruginosa in {{c1::CF}} patients. 
• Gonorrhea – norfloxacin & ofloxacin. 
• Bacterial prostatitis – norfloxacin. 
• External otitis.

Protein Translation
Covered in L.1
• Eukaryotic and prokaryotic ribosomes are different and this provides the basis for selective antimicrobial action. 

• The eukaryotic ribosome consists of a {{c1::60}}S and a {{c1::40}}S subunit to give a {{c1::80}}S complete ribosome. 

• The bacterial ribosome consists of a {{c1::50}}S and a {{c1::30}}S subunit to give a {{c1::70}}S complete ribosome. 

• To initiate bacterial translation mRNA must bind to the {{c1::30}}S subunit first and then bind the {{c1::50}}S. 

• The ribosome has 3 binding sites for tRNA termed {{c1::E, P and A.}}

Amphenicols
- MOA: Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the {{c1::50}}S subunit and inhibits the formation of the peptide bond. 

- Broad spectrum antibiotic, bacteriostatic for most organisms but kills {{c1::H. Influenzae}}. 

- Resistance mediated by plasmid transfer of {{c1::chloramphenicol acetyltransferase}}.

- Administration: {{c1::Chloramphenicol}} is given orally and is rapidly and completely absorbed and reaches Cmax in {{c1::2}} hours. 

- PK: Widely distributed throughout the tissues and fluids {{c1::in}}cluding CSF. 

- Excreted in the urine ({{c1::10}}% unchanged) and metabolised in the liver. 

- Side effects: GI disturbances and hypersensitivity reactions. 

- Rare side effects include {{c1::pancytopenia (decrease in all blood cell types).}}

Uses of Chloramphenicol
• Should be reserved for serious infections as side effects can be serious ({{c1::haematological}} toxicity). 
• Resistant Haemophilus {{c1::influenzae}} infections. 
• Meningitis where patients can’t take penicillin. 
• Conjunctivitis (safe when given {{c1::topically}}). 
• Typhoid fever

Macrolides 
• {{c1::Lactone}} ring structure. 

• Inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit by preventing {{c1::translocation}} movement of the ribosome along mRNA. 

• Examples: erythromycin, clarithromycin and azithromycin. 

• Broad spectrum - {{c1::erythromycin}} is a safe alternative to penicillin sensitive patients. 

• Resistance can occur from a plasmid controlled alteration in the binding site for erythromycin on the ribosome. 

• Erythromycin is effective against Gram {{c1::+}}ve but not Gram {{c1::–}} ve bacteria. 

• Clarithromycin and azithromycin are effective against H. influenzae.

• Administered {{c1::orally}}. 

• Distribute to most tissues and {{c1::do not}} cross the BBB, poorly penetrates the synovial joints . 

• Accumulate in phagocytes and eliminated in the {{c1::bile}}. 

• {{c1::Erythr}}omycin is partly inactivated in the liver, {{c1::azithr}}omycin is resistant to inactivation and {{c1::clarithr}}omycin is converted to an active metabolite. 

• Their inhibition of P450 enzymes can affect the bioavailability of some drugs e.g. Theophylline. 

• Side effects include GI disturbances, opportunistic infections and hypersensitivity reactions - rashes and fever.

Tetracyclines
• Broad-spectrum antibiotics. 

• Uptake by {{c1::active transport}}. 

• Inhibit protein synthesis by interfering with the attachment of {{c1::tRNA}} to mRNA. 

• Bacteriostatic not bactericidal. 

• Examples: tetracycline, doxycycline, minocycline.

• Given orally but can be given parenterally. 

• Absorption varies but is improved in the {{c1::absence}} of food. 

• Bonds metal ions (Ca2+, Mg2+, Fe2+, Al3+) forming complexes. 

• Absorption is {{c1::de}}creased with milk and antacids. 

• GI disturbances (loss of microbiota), deposited in growing bones and teeth – bone & teeth deformities.

Uses of Tetracyclines 
• Use has declined due to {{c1::widespread resistance}}. 
• Broad spectrum – Gram {{c1::+ve & -ve}} bacteria, protozoa, mycoplasma & spirochetes. 
• Respiratory tract infections - chronic bronchitis. 
• Chlamydia, anthrax, brucellosis. 
• As an alternative to patients with allergies. 
• Acne

Aminoglycosides
Changes shape of 30S subunit causing an abnormal anticodon-codon interaction and misreading of the mRNA. 

• Their crossing of the bacterial cell membrane depends on active transport. • Its effect is bactericidal. 

• Resistance can be due to degradation by microbial enzymes or blocking cell entry. 

• Function is enhanced with β-lactams. 

• Effective against a wide range of aerobic Gram –ve and some Gram +ve bacteria; low activity with anaerobes. 

• Examples: streptomycin, gentamicin, neomycin.

- Aminoglycosides are {{c1::cati}}ons and highly polar so are {{c1::not ab}}sorbed by the GIT. 

- Administration: Given intramuscularly (i.m.) or i.v.;  {{c1::can}} cross the placenta and {{c1::not}} the BBB. 

- PK: Elimination is by the kidney (glomerular filtration) with {{c1::50}}% being unchanged. 

- Side-effects: Dose related toxic effects include nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity - {{c1::serum levels}} should be monitored. 

- Ototoxicity by destruction of sensory cells in the cochlea and results in vertigo or loss of balance. 

- Nephrotoxicity is manifested by damage to the nephron {{c1::tubules}} and can prevent its own excretion – accumulation causes further damage. 

- Used with infections by Gram {{c1::–ve}} bacteria e.g. E. coli.

Tuberculosis
• Contagious infection caused by an airborne bacteria – {{c1::Mycobacterium tuberculosis}}. 

• Usually affects the lungs but can also affect {{c1::any organ}}.

Therapy
• Monotherapy is ineffective (recognised since 1952 with the failure of streptomycin). 

• Multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) and extensive drug resistant TB (XDR-TB). 

• In countries where TB is prevalent, people with HIV/AIDS are {{c1::20}} times more likely to contract TB. 

• Long-term and multidrug therapeutic approach, with two steps in treatment. 

• Initial intensive (bactericidal) phase ({{c1::2}} months): mycobacteria with a high replication rate are killed resulting in clinical recovery. 

• Continuation (sterilizing) phase ({{c1::4}} months): oriented to eliminating semi-dormant bacteria

Dosing Regimes
Was a question so know this
• The initial phase treatment involves two bactericidal drugs ({{c1::isoniazid}} and {{c1::rifampicin}}), {{c1::ethambutol}} to inhibit monoresistant strains, and {{c1::pyrazinamide}} which acts on the semidormant bacteria. 

• During the continuation phase and in drug-susceptible TB, two drugs are sufficient ({{c1::isoniazid and rifampicin, same as above}}). 

• Treatment of MDR-TB is much more complicated
{{c1::}}

Isoniazid
• Antibacterial action is limited to mycobacterium. 

• Inhibits synthesis of {{c1::mycolic acid}}, an important constituent to the mycobacterium cell wall. 

• Bacteriostatic but can kill dividing cells. 

• Prodrug that must be activated by bacterial enzymes. 

• PK: Readily absorbed from the GI tract and is widely distributed through most tissues and fluids and {{c1::can}} cross BBB. 

• Penetrates deep into necrotic lesions caused by infection

PK: Metabolism is by acetylation – ‘slow’ and ‘fast’ acetylators. 

• Determined by polymorphisms of enzyme {{c1::NAT2 (N-acetyl transferase)}}. 

• Slow acetylators have a better therapeutic response, but can lead to toxicity. 

• Excreted via kidney partly unchanged, partly acetylated. 

• Side effects: include {{c1::allergic skin}} reactions. 

• May interact with other drugs by inhibiting metabolism of phenytoin and carbamazepine which leads to toxicity of these drugs

Rifampicin 
• Inhibits {{c1::RNA polymerase}} in prokaryotic but not eukaryotic cells. 

• Effective against leprosy and some Gram {{c1::+ve & -}}ve bacteria. 

• It can enter {{c1::phagocytes}} and therefore reach Mycobacterium. 

• PK: Given orally and widely distributed in tissues and fluids. 

• Excreted by the kidneys and bile. 

• Metabolite {{c1::retains}} antibacterial activity. 

• Side effects: not frequent but include fever, skin rashes and GI disturbances. 

• Drug interactions: Can cause induction of metabolising enzymes and can lead to an increase in degradation of {{c1::warfarin}} and {{c1::oestrogens (contraceptive pill)}}.

Ethambutol 
• Only affects mycobacterium: bacteriostatic effect. 

• PK: Given orally, well absorbed 

• Taken up by {{c1::RBCs}} in blood, partly metabolised and excreted in the kidney. 

• Side effects: include {{c1::optic neuritis – red-green colour blindness}}

Pyrazinamide 
• Effective at {{c1::low and not neutral}} pH (tuberculostatic). 

• Mycobacterium at {{c1::low}} pH inside phagolysosomes. 

• PK: Orally well absorbed, well distributed, excreted by the kidney. 

• Side effect: include gout (urate in blood)

Bedaquiline: 
• Target is mycobacterial {{c1::ATP}} synthase (unique mechanism), metabolised by p450. 

• {{c1::Rifampicin}} induces this enzyme thus reducing plasma concentrations of bedaquiline. 

• Seems to have promise as an adjunct treatment on MDRTB and XDR-TB.

Delamanid: 
• Incompletely understood but may involve inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis, a prodrug requiring metabolism by {{c1::mycobacterial}} enzymes. 

• Currently being investigated in MDR-TB and XDR-TB

Viruses
• Small infective agents consisting of nucleic acid (RNA or DNA) enclosed in a protein coat. 
• They are not cells, and utilise the metabolic processes of the host cell that they infect in order to replicate. 

• DNA viruses: {{c1::usually enter the host cell nucleus and direct the generation of new viruses. }}

• RNA viruses: {{c1::direct generation of new viruses without involving the host cell nucleus.}} 

• RNA retroviruses: {{c1::possess reverse transcriptase which makes a DNA copy of the viral RNA, which is then integrated into the host cell genome and directs the generation of new virus particles}}

HIV and AIDS
• HIV: RNA retrovirus (HIV-1, responsible for human AIDS and HIV-2, largely confined to Africa less virulent). 

• Interaction of HIV with the host’s immune system is complex, primarily involving cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs, CD{{c1::8+}} T cells) and helper T lymphocytes (CD{{c1::4+}} cells). 

What is CTL?
{{c1::
A cytotoxic T cell (also known as TC, cytotoxic T lymphocyte, CTL, T-killer cell, cytolytic T cell, CD8+ T-cell or killer T cell) is a T lymphocyte (a type of white blood cell) that kills cancer cells, cells that are infected (particularly with viruses), or cells that are damaged in other ways.

• CTLs directly kill virally infected cells, and produce and release antiviral cytokines, whilst CD4+ cells may have a direct role in the control of HIV replication. 
}}

• HIV is incorporated with the host DNA and can remain latent for a prolonged period. Mutations in the HIV genome enable the HIV to escape recognition by the original cytotoxic lymphocytes, requiring the production of new lymphocytes that ultimately can “exhaust” the immune system

Antiviral drugs
• Selectivity for viruses is difficult as they reside within the host cell. 

• Some enzymes are virus-specific and thus are useful drug targets. 

• Most antivirals are effective only when the viruses are {{c1::replicating}}. 

• Antivirals are grouped according to their mechanisms of action and side effects.

Nucleoside Reverse transcriptase inhibitors 
• Nucleoside analogues: {{c1::phosphorylated}} by host cell enzymes to give the 5’-triphosphate. 

• This competes with the host cell triphosphates essential for pro-viral DNA production, thus causing DNA chain termination. 

• Examples: zidovudine ({{c1::thymidine}} analogue), whilst newer NRTIs ({{c1::abacavir}}) have less toxicity. 

• Non-nucleoside RTIs: do not require phosphorylation. 

• Bind to the reverse transcriptase causing a conformational change reducing its activity. 

• Example: nevirapine. 

• Most are potent inducers of {{c1::Cyt P450}}

Protease inhibitors 
• Bind to HIV proteases, blocking the {{c1::proteolytic}} activity. 

• Resulting in the provirus being translated into two biochemically inert polyproteins. 

• Protease inhibitors prevent the cleavage of the nascent viral protein into functional and structural proteins.

• Example: {{c1::ritonavir}}. 

• Low likelihood of resistance. 

• {{c1::Ritonavir}} is a potent CYP{{c1::3A4}} inhibitor

DNA polymerase inhibitors 
• {{c1::Aciclovir}} is the prototype drug. 

• It is a guanosine derivative that is converted to the monophosphate by viral {{c1::thymidine}} kinase. 

• More effective than the host cell enzyme (e.g. {{c1::30}} times more effective against the herpes virus enzyme than the host enzyme). 

• Host cell kinases then convert the monophosphate to the {{c1::tri}}phosphate, which inhibits viral DNA {{c1::polymerase}} terminating the nucleotide chain. 

• Resistance occurs by changes in the viral genes coding for {{c1::thymidine}} kinase or DNA {{c1::polymerase}}

HIV integrase inhibitors 
• Acts by inhibiting HIV DNA integrase. 

• Prevents the formation of {{c1::covalent}} bonds between the host and viral DNA. 

• Prevents the incorporation of viral DNA into the host genome when forming the provirus. 

• Example: {{c1::ratelgravir}}. 

• Used in the treatment of HIV as part of a combination therapy, due to its potency and low potential for side effects and drug interactions.

Inhibitors of viral entry/fusion:
Chemokine receptor antagonists: 
• {{c1::CCR5}}, together with {{c1::CXCR4}}, are cell surface chemokine receptors that are exploited by some HIV strains to gain entry into the cell. 

• Example: {{c1::maraviroc}} a chemokine receptor antagonist used in combination with other drugs.

Fusion Inhibitors: 
• Prevents the conformational changes necessary for the fusion of the viral and cellular membrane. 

• Example: {{c1::Enfuviritide}} 

• Its novel mechanism means no cross resistance with other antiretrovirals.

• Needs to be administered {{c1::parenterally}}

Immunomodulators
• Immunoglobulin: these are antibodies against various viruses. 

• {{c1::Palivisumab}}: a monoclonal antibody directed against a glycoprotein on the surface of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). 

• Interferons (IFNs): family of inducible proteins (alpha, beta and gamma). 

• IFNs bind to specific receptors on host cell membranes that then induce the production of enzymes that inhibit the translation of viral mRNA into viral proteins, thus stopping viral replication. 

• Need to be administered intravenously, {{c1::do not}} cross BBB.

Combination therapy for HIV
• Different agents targeting different steps results in synergistic or additive antiviral effects. 

• HAART (highly active antiretroviral therapy) typically consists of two {{c1::nucleoside RTIs}} with either a nonnucleoside RTI or one/two {{c1::protease}} inhibitors. 

• Other drugs, such as the HIV integrase inhibitor ratelgravir, the chemokine receptor antagonist marviroc and the HIV fusion inhibitor enfurvitide may also be used in combination therapy. 

• Some patients may experience treatment failure and require more complex therapy
